children.value: class (like its lower level counterpart, the
) manages an "array" of values ("buffers") that will be made available as input data to shaders during a draw call. For each WebGL
also stores some additional information about how that data in the buffer should be accessed, such as offsets, strides, etc, and whether the attribute is instanced.
class provides the following features on top of the lower level
Reads a "program configuration", enabling attributes to be set using names instead of locations
Avoids duplicating information already specified in shaders, such as size and type of attributes.
Automatic deduction of draw parameters from currently set attributes
Handles the "constant attribute 0" complication that is common on desktop WebGL browsers.
Can generated debug output of attribute bank
Can fall back to sharing single
is a wrapper class around the
class which encapsulates the underlying WebGL object. The

It is usually not necessary to create
instances in luma.gl applications. The application can just supply a map of

class, and rely on that class to automatically manage the vertex attributes array and supply it to any draw calls (e.g. when rendering, picking etc). Still, it can be useful to review this documentation to better understand how attributes are handled.

- Sets the frequency divisor used for instanced rendering (instances that pass between updates of attribute). Usually simply set to 1 or 0 to enable/disable instanced rendering. 0 disables instancing, >=1 enables it.
The application can enable normalization by setting the
The application can disable integer to float conversion when running under WebGL2, by setting the
data formats and locations of vertex attributes. Values are always left as integer values. Only accepts the integer types gl.BYTE, gl.UNSIGNED

in attributes: Instanced attributes requires WebGL2 or a (widely supported) WebGL1 extension. Apps can use the luma.gl feature detection system to determine if instanced rendering is available, though the extension is so ubiquitously supported that many apps just make the assumption:
An attribute is referred to as
if its divisor value is non-zero.
The divisor modifies the rate at which vertex attributes advance when rendering multiple instances of primitives in a single draw call.
If divisor is zero, the attribute at slot index advances once per vertex.
If divisor is non-zero, the attribute advances once per divisor instances of the set(s) of vertices being rendered.
